title: George kept Lennie's dream alive, they had their dream and they had each other.
image: Lennie and George are sat at a small table. They have been given work on one of the ranches.
relate_to_story: George tells Lennie not to mess up. Lennie just wants to hear about the rabbits
quote: Guys like us, that work on ranches, are the loneliest guys in the world. They got no family. They don't belong no place. They come to a ranch an' work up a stake and then they go inta town and blow their stake, and the first thing you know they're poundin' their tail on some other ranch. They ain't got nothing to look ahead to.
quote_context: George is explaining to Lennie why they are different from other ranch workers. He emphasizes their unique bond and shared dream, which sets them apart from the loneliness that characterizes the lives of itinerant workers during the Great Depression.
critical_points: George and Lennie's relationship is central to the story, highlighting themes of friendship and loyalty.
The dream of owning a piece of land symbolizes hope and the pursuit of the American Dream.
The quote reflects the isolation and loneliness experienced by many during the Great Depression.
George's protective nature towards Lennie showcases the depth of their bond and the sacrifices he makes for him.
The contrast between George and Lennie's dream and the harsh reality of their lives underscores the theme of unattainable dreams.
